<[silence:3400]>
Genetic bottlenecks. Survival trade-offs.
<[silence:2400]>
"Captive breeding" means raising animals in zoos or labs to save species from extinction.<[silence:1200]>
But it’s like copying a book over and over—mistakes pile up.<[silence:2400]

Zoos pick the "best" animals to breed, often the same few, shrinking the gene pool.<[silence:1200]>
Wild cheetahs have 99% genetic diversity; captive ones? As low as 1% in some cases.<[silence:1200]>
This inbreeding weakens immunity—like California condors, where 80% of chicks died from a single virus in the 1990s.<[silence:2400]

Even if they survive, captive-bred animals struggle in the wild.<[silence:1200]>
Black-footed ferrets, raised in labs, forgot how to hunt prairie dogs—their main food.<[silence:1200]>
Releasing them was like handing a chef a live chicken and no knife.<[silence:2400]

Costs soar too.<[silence:1200]>
Breeding a single whooping crane chick? $100,000.<[silence:1200]>
For that price, you could protect 100 wild nests for a year.<[silence:2400]

Habitat loss. Climate shifts. Disease spillover.<[silence:1200]>
Captive breeding buys time—but time for what?<[silence:1200]>
De-extinction. Assisted migration. Genetic rescue.<[silence:1200]>
The clock’s ticking.
